Articles.Content:
India's GSLV Mk. III rocket is planned to fly it's first mission at about 4:00 UTC/GMT (i.e. 23 hours after this post). Live coverage should be available here(Indian national news), here(directly from ISRO), and via youtube

The payload is a prototype for an Indian crewed capsule, CARE, the full version of which is planned to fly on Mk. III sometime after 2020.

Edited December 17, 2014 by Kryten

What is all that grey stuff? Is it a Soyuz-like interstage?

I see no engine nozzle.

Also, are those mini-boosters on the sides of the... well, boosters?
The gap is between the oxidiser and fuel tanks of the (simulated, in this flight) upper stage, and the tanks on the boosters are part of the thrust vectoring mechanism.
The gap is for gas expansion in the second stage. I'm guessing it's similar to Soyuz where the second stage ignites before separation.
No, look closer-the engine's nowhere near it. GSLV I and II had the same feature, although less obviously (black on black). Presumably it's a weightsaving measure
If I'm understanding Wikipedia correctly, the two solid boosters fire first, and the core stage isn't ignited until 113 seconds after liftoff. That's pretty cool. And it's hypergolic.

If I'm understanding Wikipedia correctly, the two solid boosters fire first, and the core stage isn't ignited until 113 seconds after liftoff. That's pretty cool. And it's hypergolic.

Cryogenic actually.
First (second?) stage is hypergolic. The second (third?) stage would be cryogenic, but for this flight it's a dummy.

First (second?) stage is hypergolic. The second (third?) stage would be cryogenic, but for this flight it's a dummy.

Oh your talking about the solids, yeah. All liquid stages are cryo. Also yes it is confirmed that it goes boosters->core stage 1->core stage 2.
The first liquid stage uses exactly the same Vikas engines as existing GSLV and PSLV models. ISRO have plans for a kerolox first stage in the future ULV, but none for cryogenic booster stages.

The core stage 1 is hypergolic. Check out ISRO's website.

http://www.isro.org/

Your right! Those Indian guys on a different forum lied to me! D:<

I should have known, they have loads of trouble with upper stage cryo's as it is.

Your right! Those Indian guys on a different forum lied to me! D:<

I should have known, they have loads of trouble with upper stage cryo's as it is.

The cryo stage is still under development and will be tested in 2015.The core stage is Hypergolic and will be replaced by a 2000 KN RP1/LOX engine in 2019.
Webcast begins in 5 minutes
launch in 22 minutes
the ISRO link is better than youtube; no big logo or annoying youtube comments
5 minutes to launch
Alright then, a job well done by ISRO there. A pretty handsome rocket coming off the pad to boot. 10/10
Success ! the Launch of the GSLV Mk-3 was completely successful. the CARE crew module has splashed down and will be retrieved by the Indian Navy
the chairman has just reported that the S-200 boosters and the liquid core stage has performed as expected.
My favorite part of the pre-mission, we need startup sequences in KSP
The CARE director has confirmed that the capsule Beacon is transmitting and the navy is now moving to retrieve it.

So - I woke up this morning and had a thought. Does ISRO have any plans for extending the first liquid stage? If they ignited the liquid engines at liftoff and put enough extra fuel in the tanks so that the engines could burn through SRB separation and on for another few minutes like they usually do, what would that do to the rocket's payload capacity?

It would probably simpler to do this than to design a new rocket. The L-110 engines might have to be tweaked to enable them to burn for the extra time, and obviously they would need bigger tanks, but it seems like it might be worth doing. It can do 10,000kg to LEO as is, but how much extra could they get out of it?

*EDIT* I read up-thread that they are planning on replacing the hypergolics with RP-1/LOX in a few years. If they do that, they might have a man-worthy rocket here. If they can get some extra payload capacity out of it, well the Apollo CSM was only about 15,000kg, and things might get interesting.

Edited December 18, 2014 by Dkmdlb

Sorta like Energia M then??

Isn't it??

Sorta like Energia M then??

Isn't it??

Not really:

E-M GLSV-MK3

Boosters : RP-1/LOX Solid

Core :LH2/LOX HP, RP-1/LOX

2nd stage:LH2/LOX LH2/LOX
